speaker: Frasier
text: ...and though washing one's hands twenty to thirty times a day  would be considered obsessive/compulsive, please bear in mind  that your husband is a coroner.  Thank you for your call,  Jeanine.  Roz, whom do we have next?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Ethan on line three, and he's having a little problem  at school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Ethan.  I'm listening.

speaker: Ethan
text: Hi, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: How old are you?

speaker: Ethan
text: I'm thirteen.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah well, what can I do for you?

speaker: Ethan
text: Well, I'm having a lot of problems with the other kids at  school.  They're always beating me up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why do you think that's so?

speaker: Ethan
text: Probably because I'm smart.  I have a 160 IQ.  I'm in the  astronomy club and I hate sports.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, Ethan, the other children are just acting out  of jealousy and immaturity, and I... I know it doesn't help  much right now, but the day will come in the next few years  when you will have the last laugh.

speaker: Ethan
text: ...That's it?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_surprised_] Yes.

speaker: Ethan
text: Frankly, Dr. Crane, I find that advice patronizing, simplistic  and, in all candor, uninspired.  The real surprise here is  that they pay you to dole out this balloon juice.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ethan, where are you calling from?

speaker: Ethan
text: Home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if any of Ethan's classmates are listening, you know  where he is, and he can't stay in there forever.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_maliciously_] Thank you for your call! [_disconnects Ethan_]  Well, that's about it for today.  This is Frasier Crane,  KACL Talk Radio, 780 AM.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Roz, I thought that was a pretty good show, didn't you?

speaker: Roz
text: [_touching up her makeup_] Yeah, sure.  Whatever you say.

speaker: Frasier
text: You seem a bit distracted there, Roz.  You got another one of  your hot dates?

speaker: Roz
text: If you must know, yes.

speaker: Noel
text: Pick you up outside in five minutes?

speaker: Roz
text: Great.  Thanks, Noel.

speaker: Frasier
text: Noel?  Noel Shempsky from Sales, that's who your date's with?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, it's not a date.  We're just going out for a drink, okay?

speaker: Frasier
text: Noel the Mole?

speaker: Roz
text: I know, he's not great-looking.  I know he drives a '73 Dodge  Polaris.  But he's always struck me as a really interesting guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mm-hmm...

speaker: Roz
text: Look, the world is loaded with superficial guys.  You know,  I just want to go out with someone who has a good heart.  He's  smart.  He's substantial - and you know, considering my track  record lately I would hope you'd support me.  Is that asking  too much?

speaker: Frasier
text: Does Noel still have that autographed picture of Captain Kirk  in his cubicle?

speaker: Roz
text: Why do I tell you anything?  _She leaves.    FADE OUT_  **BOY N THE HOOD**  _Scene B: Frasier's Apartment, kitchen.  Daphne is baking as Niles enters._

speaker: Niles
text: Knock, knock.  Can I be of any assistance?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no thank you, Dr. Crane, I think I have everything under  control.

speaker: Niles
text: Do you mind if I linger then?  I've always been sort of a  kitchen person.

speaker: Daphne
text: Suit yourself.  I like the company.  _As they converse, Niles tries, but fails, to boost himself onto  the counter to sit._

speaker: Niles
text: How's dad's therapy going?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, we're getting more mobility in his hip, and his  flexibility's improving, but it's always a chore to get  him to do his exercises.  Of course, I've found the secret  is if I bribe him with sweets...  _Niles takes a jump at the countertop and bangs his head on the extraction  hood, bounces off the refrigerator and ends up on the floor._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh my goodness!

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane!  Dr. Crane, can you get up?

speaker: Niles
text: No.  No, I think I'd better stay here for a few minutes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God, I thought I heard...!  Niles, what are you doing?  [_drags Niles to his feet_]

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm afraid he conked his head, on the hood there.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Niles_] You are shameless!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I have a very sore head and a crackerjack lawyer,  so don't crowd me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Here. [_gives Niles a wet cloth_] Put this on it.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you, Daphne.  You've been wonderful in this time of  crisis.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, Camille!

speaker: Frasier
text: I need to talk to you.  Here, have a seat, right here.  Now listen Niles, I'm having a young lady over on Friday  night, I was hoping you could take Dad out for me.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I wish you'd said Saturday.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why, you have plans Friday?

speaker: Niles
text: No, I have plans Saturday.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, just tell me that you'll do this for me?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, all right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: So... does this mean you're hoping to get lucky Friday night?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, please.  Nobody refers to having sex as "getting  lucky" anymore.

speaker: Niles
text: I do.

speaker: Martin
text: Hello, boys.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad. [_motions to Niles to do his party piece_]

speaker: Niles
text: Dad?  I was wondering if you'd be interested in joining Maris  and me Friday night.  We're dying to try the new rib joint  that's opened on Bellevue Way.  I understand if the onion  rings aren't as big as your head you get them for free.

speaker: Martin
text: Well thanks, Niles, but I thought I'd spend a quiet evening at  home.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, well then... [_Frasier pushes him_] Better yet, why don't  you come to our house?  We'll make dinner, and we'll even rent  an Angie Dickinson film.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh!

speaker: Martin
text: All right, what's going on?  Frasier wants me out of here  because he has a date or something?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, Frasier, he sees things that others don't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm sorry, Dad.  I guess I should have asked you myself.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that's all right. [_sitting in his chair_] Yeah, I'll clear  out.  But just remember, one hand washes the other around  here.

speaker: Frasier
text: What does that mean?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, as long as I'm clearing out for you Friday night,  you can clear out for me Thursday night.  I've got a date  with Elaine Morris from 14-12.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!  Well, well.  How long has this been going on?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, she's had me over for coffee a couple of times.  Just  thought I'd like to have her over here for dinner. [_without  looking back_] Niles, wipe that stupid smirk off your face.  [_Niles looks offended_] What do you say, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, sure Dad.  I think that's terrific.  Oh listen, if there's  a lull in the conversation, we've got all kind of board games  back here in the closet, we got playing cards - does she like  to play Canasta?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh! - and PBS is running a wonderful documentary on the swing  bands of the 30's and 40's.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, wow...

speaker: Martin
text: Well, thanks a lot for all your help, boys, but I think we'll  just split a bowl of creamed corn, rub a little liniment into  each other's joints and fall asleep drooling on the couch!   **FOOT IN MOUTH DISEASE**  _Scene C: Frasier's Apartment, Kitchen.  Friday morning.  Daphne is making breakfast at the stove.  Frasier  comes in wearing his dressing gown and pours himself coffee._

speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Good morning, Dr. Crane.  I want to thank you again for the  show last night.  I've never been to experimental theatre  before.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't mention it.  It was my pleasure.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I think I understood most of it.  Only what did it mean  when the naked man came in, carrying a suitcase?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_after a pause_] I think it meant that he's packed too much.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm sure your father appreciated having us out of the  house.

speaker: Frasier
text: What is that heavenly aroma?

speaker: Daphne
text: I decided to prepare us a traditional English breakfast.  We have eggs, bangers - or as you call them, sausages--  and to finish it off...

speaker: Daphne
text: A batch of Grammy Moon's famous sticky buns!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_smelling_] Oh my, that's it!

speaker: Daphne
text: Grammy made these every Sunday.  'Course, she added a pint of  rum to the recipe.  And nobody liked these more than Grammy  herself.  Many's the Sunday I'd head over to her house after  church, only to find her out in the garden in her wedding  dress, facedown in the birdbath.

speaker: Martin
text: Morning.

speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, dad. So... How was your date last night, huh?  Ha, boy, feels strange, you know?  A son asking his father  how his date was last night...

speaker: Frasier
text: When he could ask the date herself!

speaker: Martin
text: Elaine, this is Daphne Moon, my son Frasier Crane, Elaine  Morris. [_they all shake hands_]

speaker: Frasier
text: So... so, it's a pleasure to meet you, Elaine.  It's ah...  I know that dad's wanted to have you for a long time - I mean,  for dinner!

speaker: Elaine
text: Yes.  Well, I certainly enjoyed it.  But you know, Martin,  I... I really should be going.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh no, no.  You should at least stay for breakfast, shouldn't  she, Fras?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, absolutely.

speaker: Elaine
text: Well, I guess I could stay for coffee.

speaker: Frasier
text: Splendid, splendid, splendid.  So uh -- so uh... what did you  two kids do last night?  Did you ah, play some games?  Well,  I mean, board games!  Not that you were bored - or excited...  well, not that I'd know anything - or should!  But ah... warm  buns, Elaine?  No, no, not yours!  I mean ours, ours! [_picks  up Daphne's sticky buns_] To eat, you see.  Have one, I'll have  one!  Warm!

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't we go sit at the table?

speaker: Elaine
text: Okay... [_she goes out_]

speaker: Martin
text: [_as he follows her, to Frasier_] What the hell's wrong with you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know!

speaker: Elaine
text: Well, uh... Frasier, you know, I really love your radio show.  My friends and I listen to it almost every day.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  That's always lovely to hear.

speaker: Martin
text: Elaine's a buyer at Beaumarchais.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh really, really?  I do-do a great deal of shopping there.  As a matter of fact, I bought the comforter on dad's bed  there, and, well, I supposed you noticed that... maybe you  didn't - I mean, I don't know if you had the lights on, or...  I mean, I don't know how you like it... I mean, how you...  light it!  How you like to light it!    _Daphne comes in with a large plate of sausage patties.  Frasier  is thankful for a change of subject and seizes it._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, banger, dad?

speaker: Elaine
text: [_making for the door_] You know, I really should be going,  I've got to get ready for work, it was nice meeting you  Daphne, and uh, Frasier.  Thanks for a lovely evening,  Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: I'll call you later.

speaker: Elaine
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Daphne_] You couldn't have served bacon?

speaker: Daphne
text: Me?!  The way you were carrying on, I think we can be thankful  I didn't make Toad in the Hole! [_exits to kitchen_]

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you handled that smoothly, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, dad.  It just, really caught me off guard.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, that's ok.  I really ought to apologize.  I should have  warned you, but... I really didn't think it was going to  happen. [_smiles_] I'm pretty glad it did!

speaker: Frasier
text: So, you like Elaine?

speaker: Martin
text: I like Elaine.

speaker: Frasier
text: So, dad...

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah...

speaker: Frasier
text: You're back on the beat!

speaker: Martin
text: All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Lock up your daughters!

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, you old...

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, don't push it!    _End of Act One.    Act Two.    Scene A: Radio Station.  Roz is introducing the next caller._

speaker: Roz
text: One line one we have Marianne, she's concerned about her  daughter.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] Hello Marianne, I'm listening.

speaker: Marianne
text: Kids - you can't live with them, you can't shove them back in  the womb.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as we try to forget the image that that summons up,  how can I help you, Marianne?

speaker: Marianne
text: Well, two days ago, Judy, my twenty-two year old, arrived  home for a visit with her boyfriend.  I insisted that they  sleep in separate bedrooms.  She got furious with me, and  she's been giving me dirty looks all week.   Am I completely  out of line here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not at all.  I, I think that in your own house you make up  the rules.

speaker: Marianne
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: But... are we sure there isn't something else going on here?  Perhaps you're having a problem thinking of your daughter as  an adult.  You see, we all have a tendency to freeze people  in roles with which we are most comfortable.  Especially when  it comes to that old bugaboo, sex.  You know, let me use  myself as an example.  As many of you know, my sixty-three  year old father recently moved in with me and, just this  morning over coffee, I discovered he had spent the night in  his room with a delightful creature named Elaine.  The entire  episode completely unnerved me.  Why?  Because I had never  thought of my father as a man with normal sexual urges.  To me he was always old plain old Dad.  Well, that's absurd.  My father is a witty, virile, charming man, possessed of the  hereditary Crane good looks, and what I suppose I'm driving  at is, that sexuality is a healthy part of adulthood, at any  age.  I think it's time we embrace that, don't you, Marianne?  Maryanne: Sorry, Dr. Crane, I gotta go.  I'm hearing noises from the  guest room. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as Marianne rushes to the guest room with a bucket of  ice water, we will pause for these messages. [_off air_]

speaker: Roz
text: Hey Frasier, that was a really good show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you.  I thought so too.

speaker: Noel
text: Hi, Dr Crane. [_lovelorn_] Hi, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Noel.

speaker: Noel
text: I had a great time last night.

speaker: Roz
text: Me, too.

speaker: Noel
text: I made you this spice rack. [_hands it over_] I especially  treated The back for easy wall adhesion.

speaker: Roz
text: [_who has already found that out_] That was very thoughtful of  you, Noel.

speaker: Noel
text: Well um, I gotta run.  I'll call you later. [_gives the Vulcan  peace salute_] Live long and prosper.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh look, there's a place for cumin, most people overlook that.

speaker: Roz
text: Just kill me.  _Scene B: Frasier's Apartment.  Martin and Daphne are there.  Martin is furious._

speaker: Martin
text: I don't understand it.  Why would he say something like that  on the radio?

speaker: Daphne
text: Did you know, when you get angry your ears turn red? [_Martin  glares at her_] See?  There they go.

speaker: Frasier
text: Evening, everyone.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll be going to my room right now. [_leaves, hurriedly_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Eddie. [_Eddie chases after Daphne_] Well, I seem to have  cleared the room.

speaker: Martin
text: I want to talk to you, mister.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, sounds like someone's being taken out behind the woodshed.

speaker: Martin
text: Don't tempt me.  Where the hell do you get off talking about  my personal life on your radio program?

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you discussing what I said about you and Elaine?

speaker: Martin
text: You're damned right I am.  I've never been so embarrassed in  my Life.

speaker: Frasier
text: But dad, everything I said was flattering.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.  Telling all of Seattle about your old dad shacking  up with the neighbor lady.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on you old swordsman, I thought you'd get a kick out  of it.

speaker: Martin
text: Knock it off, Frasier.  Thanks to you Elaine won't even talk  to me anymore.

speaker: Frasier
text: What for?  Just because of a harmless remark I made on the  radio?

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, for your information, people of our generation think sex  is a private thing.  And I still think that's a pretty healthy  way of looking at it.  Sex is something between you, and the  person you're doing it to!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, don't you think she's overreacting?

speaker: Martin
text: Put yourself in her place.  She takes a chance and spends the  night with me.  Next thing she knows, it's being broadcast all  over Seattle.  I mean, her friends heard it and called her.  She's so embarrassed she's never been out of the house all  day, she won't even answer the phone now.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Your sympathy touches me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well look, look.  I caused a problem here, and I will take  care of it.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah?  Well, I'll be in my room, holding my breath.

speaker: Frasier
text: I said I'd take care of it!  _Scene C: Radio Station.  Both Frasier and Roz are bored, listening to a caller (Al),  who has the most tedious voice, ever._

speaker: Al
text: [_on air; tired, listless monotone_] I hate my voice.  I mean,  I know no-one likes the sound of their own voice, especially  when they hear it on tape.  Because it doesn't sound as good  as it does in their own head.  But I hate my voice in my head  too.    [_Frasier finds himself a backscratcher.  Roz is eating Chinese takeout  in her booth._]

speaker: Al
text: And you can't get away from your own voice either, you know.  I've tried not listening to myself when I talk.  But I find  myself kinda saying things that don't make a lot of sense...  _Frasier starts playing around with the backscratcher, making Roz laugh.  He rolls down his sleeve and holds out the backscratcher like it's his  hand, putting it to his face in shock, then scratching his armpit._

speaker: Al
text: I hate my voice so much, I had to call a neighbor in to do the  message on my answering machine.  I don't like his voice very  much either, but it's better than mine...  _Roz sticks two chopsticks in her mouth and holds her arms to her sides  like flippers, pretending to be a walrus.  Frasier laughs._

speaker: Al
text: Not that I get a lot of calls...  _Roz slips out of her chair and tumbles to the floor.  Frasier is alarmed  for a second, but unable to stop laughing._

speaker: Al
text: Well, you go figure.  Any advice, Dr Crane?  _Quickly, Frasier and Roz resume their positions, though neither of them  has been listening to Al._

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes uh, just go on with what you're doing, and everything  should turn out all right.  Thank you for your call. [_line off_]  Now, I'd like to end today's show on something of a personal  note.  I'm talking to one person in my audience.  Elaine - you  wouldn't answer my phone calls, you wouldn't come to the door,  so I hope you're listening.  And if you are, I want to apologize  for what I said on the radio.  I took something that was of a  private nature and turned it into public knowledge.  I promise  I will never do that again - well, except for this time, then  I promise I'll never do it again.  You see, the saddest thing  is, Elaine, that uh, that dad is paying for my mistake.

speaker: Frasier
text: Elaine... Martin cares for you.  And he misses you very much.  More than anything in the world, he'd like to be back together  with you.  And if you feel for him the way he feels for you,  I hope you'll find it in your heart to come to my place  tonight, at eight o' clock, for dinner.  A very romantic  dinner.  Thanks, Elaine.  This is KACL 780 AM, talk radio.  And I'm Frasier Crane... the _Love_ Doctor.  _He crosses his fingers at Roz, then goes to commercial.    FADE TO:    Scene D: Frasier's Apartment.  He and Daphne are laying a romantic dinner table for two.  Frasier softly sings, "Moon River."_

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Well, the champagne's chilled, a platter of hors d'oeuvres,  how are things in the kitchen?

speaker: Daphne
text: The roast is out of the oven.  It looks beautiful.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, I hope this works, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I've been sending Elaine psychic messages all day.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're kidding.  You can transmit?  I thought you were just a  receiver.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm giving it a try.  You know, "Elaine in 14-10, come  to dinner, come to dinner".

speaker: Frasier
text: That's very charming, Daphne, but Elaine's in 14-12.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh dear.  I guess I'd better set an extra place at the table,  then.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah look, it's eight o' clock and I'm still a pumpkin.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, it is two minutes to eight, and why don't you just sit  down and relax?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, this is stupid.  She probably didn't even hear your show.  [_then_] Does this tie go with the jacket?

speaker: Daphne
text: You look smashing.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, who the hell am I kidding?  She's not going to show up.  I don't know why I even- [_the doorbell chimes_]

speaker: Frasier
text: May I suggest we just skip the first course, which is crow,  and move directly to the hors d'oeuvres?

speaker: Martin
text: Just shut up and answer the door.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.

speaker: Marjorie
text: Excuse me, is this the Crane residence?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes it is.

speaker: Marjorie
text: Well, we've been waiting here for the last fifteen minutes.  Did Elaine show up, or did we miss her?

speaker: Frasier
text: Who are all you people?

speaker: Woman
text: We heard your show today.

speaker: Marjorie
text: Oh, it was so romantic, we all have our fingers crossed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, very kind.

speaker: Marjorie
text: I'm Marjorie, from down on eleven...

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Marjorie.

speaker: Marjorie
text: And this is Norman...

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Norman.  It's a pleasure.

speaker: Marjorie
text: And the rest of these people I don't know.

speaker: Frasier
text: Nice to see you all. [_sees the doorman_] Tony?  Tony, what are  you doing here?  For God's sakes, shouldn't you be watching  the door?

speaker: Tony
text: Oh, don't worry, we're all locked in.  I have GOT to find out  how this ends, Doc.

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming to door_] What's going on out here?

speaker: Marjorie
text: Is that him?

speaker: Frasier
text: People, people, please.  Don't you have lives of your own?  For God's sake, beat it, scoot, scat..

speaker: Martin
text: What's happening?

speaker: Frasier
text: This is a private situation here...  _The lift doors open, revealing Elaine.  The crowd goes wild.  Shocked, Elaine tries to retreat, Frasier attempts to pull her  into the apartment._

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, please, come out here.

speaker: Elaine
text: No, I'm going home.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right then, dad, dad you come in here. [_hustles Martin  into the lift_] All right everybody, back off, just back off!  Just give us some time, please!

speaker: Elaine
text: Oh, I knew I should never have come up here, nothing's changed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Elaine, please let me try to explain.

speaker: Martin
text: You've done enough.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh dad, please, what do you happen to know...

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, over there! [_points to corner_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad!

speaker: Martin
text: Turn around!

speaker: Martin
text: Look Elaine, I'm sorry about what happened.  You've got every  right to be mad.  But I thought what we had was pretty good,  and thanks to Radio Boy here, I think most of Seattle agrees  with me.  I'd sure hate to lose it, just because of one stupid  thing.  Come on, Elaine.  I had a great time on our date the  other night.  You gonna tell me you don't feel the same way?  You may not remember... but I have warm toes.  _Elaine melts a little and smiles.  Frasier glances back in surprise,  but Martin turns him round again with a glare._

speaker: Martin
text: Anyway, it's your choice, but I sure wish you'd come and have  dinner with me.  _The lift reaches the fourteenth floor.  Elaine thinks for a moment  then presses the button for the nineteenth.  She turns around to  embrace Martin, then notices Frasier smiling at them._

speaker: Elaine
text: Who said you could turn around?    _Frasier turns back to the wall.    In the hallway outside Frasier's apartment, the crowd is still there._

speaker: Marjorie
text: Look, it's coming back up!  _The doors open, revealing Martin and Elaine in a clinch.  The crowd ooh and aah again._

speaker: Martin
text: [_as he and Elaine enter apartment_] All right, everyone. You've  had your fun.  Show's over.  Nothing more to see.  Go back to  your homes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, please folks.  Honor what the man says.  Thank you so  much for coming.  Thank you for your concern.  Let's expedite  this departure please, if you would. [_the crowd leaves_] Thank  you so much.  Goodbye. [_Daphne joins him_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I suppose we should give them their privacy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  Yes, I suppose you're right.  It's ironic, isn't it?  My sixty-three year old father with a bum hip is about to  embark on a night of romance, while the two of us, man and  woman, both attractive and eligible, and in the prime of our  lives, have nothing to do on a Saturday night.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, the answer to our problems may be right under our  noses.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes Daphne, I think it is.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right.  You go claim the washing machines, I'll go get the  laundry.
